docs.snippet: The police killing of a man with a large Facebook following and no apparent terrorist ties has focused outrage over extrajudicial killings in Pakistan.

headline.main: The Slain ‘Militant’ Was a Model, and a Karachi Police Commander Is Out

docs.snippet: Facebook faces complex questions over its prioritization of “meaningful” content in the News Feed, including whether people want that kind of content in the first place.

headline.main: The Difficulties With Facebook’s News Feed Overhaul

docs.snippet: The video, spread through Facebook Messenger, was legal to make, but illegal to distribute. Many of those charged are teenagers themselves.

headline.print_headline: Danish Police Charge 1,000 in Child Porn Case
headline.main: 1,000 Danes Accused of Child Pornography for Sharing Video of Teens

docs.snippet: The iPhone maker plans to make a $350 billion contribution to the American economy over the next five years as it capitalizes on the new tax law.
The wearable-camera maker styled itself a media company, but success is hard when the boss wastes time and resources chasing whims.

headline.print_headline: GoPro Needs to Know Its Limits
headline.main: GoPro Needs to Know Its Limits

docs.snippet: In a Facebook Live chat, four retired Times staff members described their dramatic 1971 retreat to a Midtown hotel to focus on preparing the Pentagon Papers.

headline.main: The Pentagon Papers Team Tells How The Times Defied Censorship

docs.snippet: Social media has put humanity in touch with a new sort of omniscience — the kind we can easily trick.

headline.main: Learning to Fool Our Algorithmic Spies

docs.snippet: Before the 2016 election, those most likely to read “fake news” online were older and conservative, a new study finds. But even they relied most often on mainstream media.

headline.print_headline: Sizing Up the Impact of Fake News
headline.main: ‘Fake News’: Wide Reach but Little Impact, Study Suggests

docs.snippet: Yes, it’s driven by greed — but the mania for cryptocurrency could wind up building something much more important than wealth.
The historian Niall Ferguson’s new book goes a long way toward redressing the lack of perspective to a concept central to the technological “revolution”: networks.

headline.print_headline: Review: Even on the Internet, What’s Old Is New Again
headline.main: Review: Even on the Internet, What’s Old Is New Again
